H0.text: Electrochemical impulses travel from neuron to neuron as information is transmitted.

H1.text: RNA strands travel from neuron to neuron as information is transmitted.

H2.text: Transport vesicles high in ATP travel from neuron to neuron as information is transmitted.

H3.text: Mechanical forces are what travel from neuron to neuron as information is transmitted.

A4.text: The signaling process is partly electrical and partly chemical. Neurons are electrically excitable, due to the maintenance of voltage gradients across their membranes. If the voltage changes by a large enough amount over a short interval, the neuron generates an all-or-nothing electrochemical pulse called an action potential.

A5.text: Beyond electrical and chemical signaling, studies suggest neurons in healthy human brains can also communicate through: force generated by the enlargement of dendritic spines

A6.text: Regularly spaced unmyelinated patches, called the nodes of Ranvier, generate action potentials to boost the signal.
